author: By Chris Buckley and Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Won’t Hesitate to Fight for Taiwan, Defense Minister Warns
description: The general said China wouldn’t “flinch from the cost” of defending its claims to the island. He spoke at a Singapore forum where he met with the U.S. defense secretary.
content: SINGAPORE — China will not flinch from war if Taiwan takes a decisive step toward independence, and it does not trust the United States’ assertions that it opposes that course for the island, the Chinese defense minister warned on Sunday, a day after Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III accused Beijing of increasingly bellicose activity near Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: She Wrote a Dystopian Novel. What Happened Next Was Pretty Dystopian.
description: Without having even been read, a book is attacked online for its fantastical premise.
content: Imagine a world in which all the men disappear from the planet in a single moment: Planes they were piloting are left unmanned (literally), their female passengers abandoned in midair; men in bed with their girlfriends mysteriously vanish; boys in the playground dematerialize before their mothers’ eyes. The girls and women left behind are given no apparent reason for the sudden absence of half the world’s population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump Is Still a Threat
description: The Jan. 6 committee hearings show how deeply Trump has altered our country.
content: Donald Trump is a cancer on this country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Two Gems of June: Premieres at Carnegie Hall and Harlem School of the Arts
description: The festival circuit may be getting underway but the city offers fine fare with programs of work by Sarah Kirkland Snider and Adegoke Steve Colson.
content: This month, you might feel the momentum in classical music swinging to the domestic festival circuit, with splashy premieres and revivals coming courtesy of Spoleto, Ojai and the Opera Theater of St. Louis. But New York isn’t finished yet, either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: Zahn McClarnon Sets His Thousand-Yard Stare on the Lead
description: AMC’s new thriller “Dark Winds” represents several firsts for the Indigenous actor, who has built a long career playing roles of quiet intensity.
content: For 30 years onscreen, Zahn McClarnon — stone-faced, soft-spoken and simmering with quiet intensity — has made a name for himself, in large part, by playing some pretty tough characters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: She Disagreed With Everything He Wrote About Housing. They Had Coffee.
description: An invitation from a reader led to a two-year correspondence with a Times reporter — and now a profile.
content: Conor Dougherty, an economics reporter for The New York Times who focuses on the West Coast, receives upward of 100 emails per day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Tough Questions for West as Ukraine Cities Teeter
description: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — With Russia about to encircle Sievierodonetsk, a city critical to its goal of seizing Ukraine’s east, and with a neighboring city squarely in Moscow’s sights, the question of how realities on the ground will shape the next phase of the war became still more pressing Sunday for Ukraine’s Western allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin, Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Amy Chang Chien
title: They Inhabited Separate Worlds in Taiwan. Decades Later, They Collided in a California Church.
description: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
content: David Chou and Pastor Billy Chang spent their whole lives forging parallel paths. They were born in early 1950s Taiwan, grew up just miles apart during martial law and later rebuilt their lives in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Newly Alarmed Sweden Concludes Military Drill With U.S. Marines
description: The drill took place on Gotland, a Swedish island in the Baltic Sea that was demilitarized after the fall of the Soviet Union, but now again seems a critical military site.
content: With tensions raised across Europe over a newly belligerent Russia, Sweden’s military and the United States Marines concluded a drill on Sunday on Gotland, a Swedish island with strategic significance for control of the Baltic Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Hostile Crowds. $3,500 Tickets. Worth It to See Stephen Curry.
description: Some Golden State fans traveled thousands of miles to Boston to watch their team face the Celtics in the N.B.A. finals.
content: BOSTON — As Stephen Curry emerged from an arena tunnel for his pregame warm-up routine, he was the center of gravity, drawing fans to him as he often does defenders on the court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Schonbrun and Hilary Swift
title: Always an Outlier, Kelsie Whitmore Just Wants to Play Baseball
description: Whitmore, a pitcher and outfielder for the Staten Island FerryHawks, is the first woman to play in a league partnered with Major League Baseball since 1994.
content: Scott Whitmore stood along the concourse on a recent spring night watching the final inning of a Staten Island FerryHawks home game wind down when a New York City police officer approached him from the third-base side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Restored Painting Recalls the Colosseum’s Christian Past
description: The restoration of a wall painting depicting an idealized Jerusalem is a reminder that the Roman monument, known best for gladiatorial combat, was a sacred Christian space for centuries.
content: ROME — For most people, the Colosseum conjures up scenes of bloody gladiatorial combat, or doomed encounters between Christians and vicious lions and tigers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: 11 Small Ways You Can Help Mend the World
description: Our problems can feel big and overwhelming. Here are everyday ways to be part of the solution.
content: In Christian liturgical churches, today is Trinity Sunday, which kicks off a long sweep of “ordinary time.” This period — which will last till mid-November — is the longest season in the church year. Ordinary time is what we call the weeks that are not included in the major seasons of feasting or fasting in the church calendar, such as Easter and Lent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah Boitey
title: ‘I Ache for Change’: Students on School Shootings After Uvalde
description: Students told us what it’s like to go to school during a time of frequent shootings, and what America should be doing about it.
content: I never feel comfortable returning to school after hearing about another shooting. I feel immense sadness, intense anger and fear. School shootings are no longer unimaginable or incomprehensible, but common and anticipated. I am 17, and many school shootings have occurred throughout my lifetime, yet I’ve seen no significant change. Instead of passing stricter gun laws, politicians have proposed armed teachers, and designing schools with a single exit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: When You’re Forced to Cash Out in a Bearlike Market
description: You can’t leave money in your I.R.A. forever, as dictated by I.R.S. rules. This can put retired investors in a tough spot.
content: Financial planners warn investors against trying to time the market. It is notoriously difficult to guess exactly when sentiment on Wall Street will reverse course — even professionals are likely to get it wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Encircles Sievierdonetsk
description: The last Ukrainian-held city in Luhansk is teetering on the brink.
content: Moscow’s forces could encircle the key city of Sievierodonetsk in eastern Ukraine and cut it off within days, the governor of Luhansk said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
title: Pro-Macron Forces Expected to Prevail but Face Left-Wing Challenge
description: The French president’s party and its centrist allies were neck and neck with a left-wing alliance in France’s first round of parliamentary elections.
content: PARIS — After a first round of voting in French parliamentary elections marked by the lowest turnout on record, President Emmanuel Macron’s party and its allies looked likely on Sunday to retain a majority even as a newly formed coalition of left-wing parties mounted a strong challenge, according to preliminary projections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: There Has to Be a Better Way to Run the Government
description: Congestion pricing in Manhattan should have happened years ago. The reason it hasn’t is instructive.
content: Two weeks ago, I wrote a column about the need for a liberalism that builds, and why it requires Democrats to confront their own role — Republican obstruction notwithstanding — in making government action difficult. This week, I want to offer a case study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Allgeier and Michael Punke
title: The World Can’t Keep Fishing Like This
description: With help from their governments, fishing boats are able to range farther, remain at sea longer and catch more fish.
content: The World Trade Organization has been struggling for over two decades to reach an agreement among its members to restrict global subsidies to the fishing industry that are pushing some fish stocks to the brink of collapse. As recently as last November, trade negotiators seemed poised to rein in these subsidies, until a spike in Covid-19 delayed the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: From Santo Domingo to the N.B.A. Finals, Al Horford Is at Home
description: Horford, the Boston Celtics center, is the first Dominican player in the N.B.A. finals. With the way he’s competing, it’s hard to tell he hasn’t been here before.
content: BOSTON — When Al Horford was 14 years old, he moved from the Dominican Republic, where he’d been raised by his mother in Santo Domingo, to Michigan, where his father and four of his half-siblings lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Trouble for Tesla?
description: Inflation recorded another increase; the Fed will probably follow with a new rate bump. And Wells Fargo is under criminal investigation.
content: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced on Thursday that it was ramping up an investigation into Tesla’s Autopilot driver-assistance system, which uses cameras and other sensors to control vehicles with little input from drivers. The agency had been conducting a preliminary evaluation of the system but upgraded to an engineering analysis, looking into whether Autopilot fails to keep drivers’ attention on the road. The new analysis brings more intense scrutiny, covering 830,000 vehicles sold between 2014 and 2021 in the United States and involving all four Tesla models; it’s also a necessary step before a recall can be ordered. Tesla tells drivers to stay alert while using the system, but many experts worry that Autopilot and similar technology can lead drivers to mistakenly believe their vehicles are completely self-driving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Alexander Nikitin, Who Coached a Chess Champion, Dies at 87
description: Garry Kasparov was just 10 when Mr. Nikitin took him on as a student. By age 17, with Mr. Nikitin as his coach, he was a grandmaster.
content: Alexander Nikitin, the principal coach of the world chess champion Garry Kasparov from the time Mr. Kasparov was 10 until years after he had become the titleholder, died on June 5 in Moscow. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Campaign Chief to Headline Jan. 6 Hearing on Election Lies
description: Bill Stepien is expected to appear alongside a fired Fox News editor who called Trump’s loss and a former U.S. attorney who resigned rather than go along with false claims of election fraud.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol plans to use the testimony of former President Donald J. Trump’s own campaign manager against him on Monday as it lays out evidence that Mr. Trump knowingly spread the lie that the 2020 election was stolen from him in an attempt to overturn his defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Abortion Politics, Money and the Reshaping of the G.O.P.
description: In “Dollars for Life,” Mary Ziegler argues that, over the course of decades, the anti-abortion movement laid the groundwork for an insurgent candidate like Donald Trump.
content: The upheavals of the last few years have been so relentless that it can be hard to recall just how weird the partnership was: Donald J. Trump and social conservatives, an odd couple for the ages. As the legal historian Mary Ziegler writes in “Dollars for Life,” the start of the 2016 election cycle had evangelicals extremely worried. Hillary Clinton — whose possible presidency they deemed “catastrophic” — was running on what Ziegler calls “arguably the most pro-choice platform in history.” Could a “foul-mouthed real estate mogul” really turn out to be “the savior they were looking for”?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After Hearings, a Tenuous Path to Indict Trump
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 12, 2022.
content: “That’s a hill that no federal prosecutor has tried to climb, prosecuting a former president. It’s very fraught. It’s a massive undertaking as an investigation, as a trial, as a national saga and trauma.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Riding Downstairs on My Building’s Service Elevator’
description: A quick stop, a Brooklyn accent gets noticed in Coney Island and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Cubs Flirted With Success. The Yankees Define It.
description: Chicago’s inability to maintain momentum after its 2016 championship underscores how unusual the Yankees’ consistency is: They are on their way to a 30th straight winning season.
content: David Ross has won the World Series twice since the last time the Yankees got there, in 2009. Both his championship teams were big spenders in big markets — first the Boston Red Sox and then the Chicago Cubs. But he never thought either team would always contend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Palin Leads Special Election for House Seat in Alaska
description: The top four candidates will advance to an August vote to finish the term of Representative Don Young, who died in March.
content: Former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska leads the 48-candidate field in a special primary election for the state’s sole congressional seat, according to a preliminary count of ballots on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Tony Award Winners 2022: Complete List
description: The Tony Awards were held Sunday at Radio City Music Hall.
content: The Tony Awards were back at Radio City Music Hall for the first time since June 2019. The awards ceremony, which honors the plays and musicals staged on Broadway and resumed its traditional calendar after a long pandemic disruption, honored work that opened on Broadway between Feb. 20, 2020, and May 4, 2022. (“Girl From the North Country” opened on March 5, 2020, just a week before theaters shut down for the pandemic.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: The Scene at the Border
description: We break down why border crossings are so high and who’s trying to come to the U.S.
content: Eileen Sullivan, a Times reporter who covers immigration, recently reported from both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border. The number of people crossing the border is the highest it’s been in at least two decades. We spoke to her about what she saw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Walters
title: Dozens of White Supremacists Arrested in Idaho Had Planned to Riot, Authorities Say
description: Members of the right-wing group Patriot Front who were charged on Saturday were preparing to disrupt a nearby Pride event, according to the police.
content: COEUR D’ALENE, Idaho — Dozens of members of a white supremacist group were arrested on Saturday in Idaho before they could act on plans to riot at a local Pride event, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus, Jack D'Isidoro, John Woo, Aaron Esposito, Dan Farrell and Lance Neal
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The “E-Pimps” of OnlyFans’
description: Clever marketers have figured out how easy it is to simulate online intimacy at scale, ventriloquizing alluring models with cheap, offshore labor.
content: Ezra Marcus takes a deep dive into the world of OnlyFans and self-described e-pimps, and untangles the vast web of models, agencies and “chatters” (the people who often act as the OnlyFans models in private messages with the customers) that support these lucrative businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Annie Karni
title: Senators Reach Bipartisan Deal on Gun Safety
description: The agreement, which falls short of the sprawling changes championed by Democrats, is a significant step toward ending a yearslong impasse over gun reform legislation.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate negotiators announced on Sunday that they had struck a bipartisan deal on a narrow set of gun safety measures with sufficient support to move through the evenly divided chamber, a significant step toward ending a yearslong congressional impasse on the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wilson
title: Crop Circles Were Made by Supernatural Forces. Named Doug and Dave.
description: Intricate patterns carved in fields across England in the 1980s were a viral phenomenon long before the internet fed us such prankster curiosities daily.
content: CONHOLT, England — Standing hip-high in a large wheat field in southern England, one can make out an odd series of depressions in the swaying green crop, where some of the wheat has been pushed down lower than the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Alderman
title: What About the Men?
description: Two speculative novels imagine rather drastic rearrangements to our existing gender relations.
content: Are women, when you get right down to it, better than men?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Lightning Will Go for a Third Straight Stanley Cup Against the Avalanche
description: No team has been to three Stanley Cup finals in a row since the Edmonton Oilers in the mid-1980s, and the Islanders were the last team to win three consecutive Cups 40 years ago.
content: No matter the sport, winning back-to-back championships titles is rare because it’s so hard. Injuries, egos, contract demands and the N.H.L. salary cap often derail second title runs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen and Matthew Goldstein
title: Goldman Sachs Is Being Investigated Over E.S.G. Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has stepped up scrutiny of sustainable investing, which has become popular but is said to lack accountability.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Goldman Sachs over its E.S.G. investment funds — funds that invest in companies that say they are committed to environmental, social and governance principles, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Celtics Got Lucky by Not Getting What They Wanted
description: Other teams’ superstars kept getting traded, and the Celtics wanted in on the action. Boston (mostly) missed out, and is probably better off for it.
content: Moments after Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals ended last month, Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown embraced each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: A Trove of Guantánamo Photos
description: A Times reporter who covers Guantánamo Bay tracked down military photographs of the early days of the U.S. detention center there.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Like so many articles, our project in Sunday’s newspaper on the once-secret Pentagon photos from the earliest days of U.S. detention operations here, in 2002, started out with a tip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: U.S. Navy Plans ‘Safety Pause’ After Series of Aircraft Crashes
description: All non-deployed aircraft will stand down for one day to “review risk-management practices and conduct training,” the Navy said.
content: In the wake of three crashes, two of them fatal, the U.S. Navy has said it will ground all nondeployed aircraft for a day on Monday to focus on safety protocols.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: The Main Draw at Andrew Giuliani’s Campaign Events? His Father.
description: Andrew Giuliani’s bid to win the Republican primary for governor of New York has not drawn many donors, but it has drawn fans of Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor.
content: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y. — On a blazing Saturday afternoon in eastern Long Island, after hours of sun-baked stump speeches by candidates of little renown, it was finally Giuliani time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Andrew Giuliani’s Vaccination Status Will Bar Him From Debate Studio
description: The Republican candidate for governor of New York is unvaccinated and says he has “natural immunity” to the coronavirus.
content: ALBANY — With the first Republican debate in the governor’s race scheduled for Monday night on WCBS-TV, the roster of in-person candidates has shrunk by one, as Andrew Giuliani — proudly unvaccinated against the coronavirus — announced on Sunday that he will not be allowed to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: How Fashion Giants Recast Plastic as Good for the Planet
description: An influential system overseen by retailers and clothing makers ranks petroleum-based synthetics like “vegan leather” as more environmentally sound than natural fibers.
content: It’s soft. It’s vegan. It looks just like leather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: How to Watch the Jan. 6 Committee Hearings
description: The second of several upcoming hearings by the House committee investigating the attack on the Capitol will be held Monday morning.
content: The House committee that has spent nearly a year investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol and the events that led up to it will hold its second public hearing on Monday morning as it expands on the themes it laid out in its initial session Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
description: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a strong majority to help him pass bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
content: PARIS — Weeks after re-electing President Emmanuel Macron, voters in France return to the polls on Sunday to choose their parliamentary representatives, elections that will determine whether Mr. Macron’s bills sail or stumble through the legislature during his second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Bolsonaro’s New Ally in Questioning Brazil’s Elections: The Military
description: Despite little evidence of past fraud, President Jair Bolsonaro has long raised doubts about Brazil’s electoral process. Now the military is expressing similar concerns.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has for months consistently trailed in the polls ahead of the country’s crucial presidential race. And for months, he has consistently questioned its voting systems, warning that if he loses October’s election, it will most likely be thanks to a stolen vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: The Art World Loves Basketballs. And Hoops and Jerseys and Backboards.
description: Fine art inspired by the sport is everywhere. One gallery filled nearly 5,000 square feet, and its curator said she “could do a Part 2 and Part 3 because there is that much work out there.”
content: The basketballs are deflated, doused in spray paint or covered in 24-karat gold leaf. They’re sculpted from porcelain, plopped in cement or layered into enormous pyramids. They’re splashed onto canvases, carved into cheeky jack-o’-lanterns, flattened out like flower petals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Vander Ploeg, Edgar Sandoval, Rick Rojas, Ali Watkins and Ashley Southall
title: ‘A Start’: Gun Deal Stirs Hope but Also Frustration in Places Scarred by Shootings
description: In Uvalde, Buffalo and Orlando, some residents see progress but lament that there hasn’t been more.
content: Americans in communities where lives have been forever changed by gun violence reacted to the bipartisan deal that was reached by Senate negotiators on Sunday with a glint of hope but more than a tinge of frustration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: At the Met This Season, Opera Was Icing on the Cake
description: Amid a labor battle, the continuing pandemic and war in Ukraine, it often felt as though the real drama was in simply putting on a show.
content: Has there ever been a Metropolitan Opera season like the one that just ended? In which the stuff onstage — the homicidal brides, mystical pharaohs and longing stepsons — felt so anticlimactic? Over the past eight months, amid a labor battle, a pandemic that surged again and again, and a war, it was as if the real drama was in simply getting the doors open. Once that was achieved, what followed was almost beside the point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and Cade Metz
title: Google Sidelines Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Sentient
description: Blake Lemoine, the engineer, says that Google’s language model has a soul. The company disagrees.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google placed an engineer on paid leave recently after dismissing his claim that its artificial intelligence is sentient, surfacing yet another fracas about the company’s most advanced technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens, Michael Paulson and Susan C. Beachy
title: Angela Lansbury wins the lifetime achievement Tony. Read her Times reviews over the decades.
description: Lansbury, 96, was not present to accept the award in person, but the New York City Gay Men’s Chorus sang “Mame” as a special tribute.
content: Angela Lansbury, a beloved star of stage, film and television, was honored on Sunday night with a special Tony Award for lifetime achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
title: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
description: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
content: PSZCZYNA, Poland — It was shortly before 11 p.m. when Izabela Sajbor realized the doctors were prepared to let her die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Sax
title: Why Strangers Are Good for Us
description: Random engagement is at the core of our social contract.
content: One Saturday morning, I took my 5-year-old son to the playground. A few minutes into his “ninja training” regimen, he attracted a fan. The other boy was younger, but the plastic glint of my son’s dollar-store sword slicing evil from the air proved irresistible. He edged closer and mimicked his moves, until they began to play together, shouting “Ya!” in unison, kicking with the verve of Rockettes. I smiled at the child’s father on the next bench and made an effort at playground banter, asking the boy’s age and whether they lived nearby. But after a few half-answers he pointed to the AirPods in his ears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Heat Wave Persists in Southwest as Temperatures Reach Record Highs
description: More than 75 million people were under heat advisories or warnings on Sunday, a day after record high temperatures were set in more than a dozen places.
content: Heat advisories and excessive heat warnings were in effect for more than 75 million people in the southern and central United States on Sunday, a continuation of a scorching heat wave that resulted in record high temperatures on Saturday in 16 cities from the Southwest to the Southern Plains, according to the National Weather Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Spindle Shuttle Needle,’ History With Strings Attached
description: With war as a backdrop, Gab Reisman’s lively comedy is content to hang out with a motley group of women at the dawn of modern capitalism.
content: A siege is terrifying. It is profoundly disorienting. It is also, as Gab Reisman argues in her lively, quasi Marxist comedy “Spindle Shuttle Needle,” kind of a bummer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Meet The Times’s New Chess Columnist
description: For Daniel Naroditsky, a career in the royal game may not be as lucrative as one at a hedge fund, but he is exactly where he wants to be.
content: Daniel Naroditsky is a chess grandmaster, the highest title given to competitors by the International Chess Federation, and he has used that talent to parlay it into a career. In addition to working as a commentator, author and chess tutor, he will be publishing his first chess puzzle on Monday in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: John R. Allen Resigns as Brookings President After Qatar Revelations
description: Mr. Allen, a retired four-star general, had been on administrative leave amid a federal inquiry into whether he had secretly lobbied for the government of Qatar.
content: John R. Allen, the retired four-star general who once commanded American troops in Afghanistan, resigned on Sunday as president of the Brookings Institution, six days after a court filing revealed evidence that he had secretly lobbied for Qatar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Jumaane Williams
description: New York City's public advocate speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
content: New York City's public advocate speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: Kathy Hochul Is the Best Choice for Democrats in the June 28 Primary
description: Kathy Hochul deserves another four years as New York's governor.
content: Kathy Hochul deserves another four years as New York's governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: The Secret Pentagon Photos of the First Prisoners at Guantánamo Bay
description: The Times obtained the pictures, taken by military photographers assigned to the elite Combat Camera team, as part of a continuing effort to chronicle the 20-year-old detention operation.
content: The Times obtained the pictures, taken by military photographers assigned to the elite Combat Camera team, as part of a continuing effort to chronicle the 20-year-old detention operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Kathy Hochul
description: New York's governor speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
content: New York's governor speaks to the New York Times editorial board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the Editorial Board
title: The New York Times Editorial Board’s Interview With Tom Suozzi

content: The Long Island congressman speaks to the New York Times editorial board.

author: By Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: McDonald’s Reopens in Russia Under New Ownership
description: The American fast-food giant sold its 840 stores to a Siberian oil mogul after pulling out from Russia this spring to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: The American fast-food giant sold its 840 stores to a Siberian oil mogul after pulling out from Russia this spring to protest President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Try Nicole A. Taylor’s newest recipes for Juneteenth, and then make a plan for saag paneer, spicy shrimp masala and more.
content: Good morning. Juneteenth is next weekend. Nicole A. Taylor put together a new menu for the holiday that’s worth considering today — recipes for those celebrating and for all those interested in the delicious: peach and molasses grilled chicken (above), for instance, and a very green coleslaw made with roasted poblanos, with watermelon ginger beer to wash it all down and a strawberry sumac cake for dessert.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 12, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 12, 2022.
content: A highlighted quotation with an article last Sunday about California’s housing crisis mis­stated Scott Wiener’s role. He is a current state senator, not a former state senator.
source.name: The New York Times
